qas.question: Why are the tops of glaciers rigid?
Which zone is the top of the glaciers?
Most crevices are no deeper than what measure?
Why is the lower 50m of a glacier rigid?
What is the free flowing upper section known as?
what forms where glaciers are unable to move?

plausible_answers.text: shear forces cause them to break apart

qas.question: What happens when two ridgid sections of a glacier collide?

plausible_answers.text: 46 m (150 ft) deep but in some cases can be 300 m (1,000 ft)

qas.question: What point do sercas form above?

context: The top 50 m (160 ft) of a glacier are rigid because <a0_0><b5_0>they are under low pressure<b5_0/><a0_0/>. This upper section is known as the <a1_0><b6_0>fracture zone<b6_0/><a1_0/> and moves mostly as a single unit over the plastically flowing lower section. When a glacier moves through irregular terrain, <b7_0>cracks called crevasses<b7_0/> develop in the fracture zone. Crevasses form due to <a2_0>differences in glacier velocity<a2_0/>. If two rigid sections of a glacier move at different speeds and directions, <b8_0>shear forces cause them to break apart<b8_0/>, opening a crevasse. Crevasses are seldom more than <a4_0><b9_0>46 m (150 ft)<a4_0/> deep but in some cases can be 300 m (1,000 ft)<b9_0/> or even deeper. Beneath this point, the plasticity of the ice is too great for cracks to form. Intersecting crevasses can create <a3_0>isolated peaks in the ice<a3_0/>, called seracs.
